data.title: Jos√© Of Belgium Was Beautiful And Twisted
data.meta_description: Marie-Jos√© of Belgium was the last Queen of Italy‚Äîlasting only a month. But her reign and life had more drama than could fit in a century.
data.text:
Marie-Jos√© of Belgium was the last Queen of Italy‚Äîlasting only a month. But her reign and life had more drama than could fit in a century.

1. She Was The Last‚ÄîBut Best

Marie-Jos√© of Belgium was queen consort of Italy from May to June of 1946, earning her the nickname ‚Äúthe May Queen‚Äù. But her short reign was full of drama, intrigue, subterfuge and scandalous affairs with history‚Äôs most controversial men. This last Queen of Italy proved to be the bravest‚Äîeven if she kept one dark secret.

2. She Was Of The Highest Pedigree

Marie-Jos√© of Belgium might have been Italy‚Äôs last queen, but she wasn‚Äôt even Italian. She was born Princess Marie Jos√© Charlotte Sophie Am√©lie Henriette Gabrielle of Belgium in Ostend. As the youngest child and only daughter of King Albert I of Belgium and Duchess Elisabeth of Bavaria, she was, however, of the highest royal pedigree.

And not just because of her very blue blood.

3. She Loved Music

From the time she was born, Marie-Jos√© had the world laid out at her feet. She was an indisputably beautiful and intelligent child with a mind and passion for the arts. She took a particular shine to music, even studying under the ‚ÄúThe King of Violin‚Äù, Eug√®ne Ysa√øe. However, she would not be able to pursue her heart‚Äôs desire.

Her parents had something else in mind.

4. Her Parents Decided Her Fate

Born in 1906, Marie-Jos√© was a member of one of the last remaining monarchies in Europe. As such, her marriage prospects became a matter of wild speculation, even in her youth. Basically, even before she was born, her parents had already decided for her. They wanted her to marry the crown prince of Italy, Umberto, whether she liked it or not.

But before she could, catastrophe got in the way.

5. She Fled The Fighting

At the outbreak of WWI, nothing mattered more to Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs parents than her safety. After all, she was destined to be the next Queen of Italy. To spare her from the worst of the fighting, her parents evacuated her to England where she boarded at the Brentwood Ursuline Convent High School in Brentwood, Essex. Only, she had some bizarre trouble fitting in.

6. She Loved Her Rabbit More Than People

As she was away from home, Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs parents had given her an escort; her father‚Äôs messenger, Major Archibald Alexander Gordon. But her true companion was a furry friend, the rabbit Marshal Soult. By all accounts, that little rabbit had more privilege and position in Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs court than the Belgian King‚Äôs Messenger. This led to a cringeworthy incident.

7. She Was A Stickler For Protocol

According to the legend, Marie-Jos√© of Belgium favored her rabbit above everyone else. So, when her escort, Major Archibald Alexander Gordon, made the mistake of referring to the rabbit simply as ‚ÄúSoult‚Äù, she scolded the courtier. The princess quipped that, if she had simply called him ‚ÄúGordon‚Äù, no one would know who she was talking about.

She would have to grow out of those childish games pretty quickly.

8. She Arrived In Italy

In an effort to prepare her to one day wear the crown in Italy, Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs parents next shipped her off to Florence, Italy. There, she studied at the all-girls College of the Santissima Annunziata. But her parents might have had ulterior motives for sending her to Italy. In fact, given what happened next, it was all part of their plan.

9. She Met Her Future Husband

During her stay in Florence, Marie-Jos√© got a massive surprise. She met the man who would become her husband; Crown Prince Umberto of Italy, Prince of Piedmont. There aren‚Äôt really any records of the couple‚Äôs first meeting but, given how their marriage eventually unfolded, it‚Äôs safe to say that it was not love at first sight. Besides, she had other things on her mind.

10. She Got The Crown Jewels

By 1924, Marie-Jos√© of Belgium made her much-anticipated social debut, attending her first court ball. But she wasn‚Äôt just your average debutante. As a true princess, she received a rare gift for the occasion: an antique pearl and diamond tiara. The sparkly artifact had originally belonged to the French princess, St√©phanie de Beauharnais.

Hopefully she enjoyed it, because her life as she knew it was about to come to an end.

11. She Became An Italian Princess

Just as her parents had planned, Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs big (and dreaded) day had finally come. On January 8, 1930, the Belgian princess dutifully walked down the aisle at the Quirinal Palace in Rome to become the Princess of Piedmont. However, the wedding was anything but magical. It was just a brief glimpse into the drama that awaited her in Italy.

12. Her Husband Broke With Convention

The big day kicked off with a terrible omen. Defying tradition (and every regular convention), Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs husband-to-be, Umberto, insisted on seeing her before the wedding. His reason? He wanted to make sure that her dress‚Äîwhich, apparently, he had helped design‚Äîwas perfect. As if that wasn‚Äôt bad enough, he made Marie-Jos√© very uncomfortable with his next move.

13. Her Husband Ruined Her Wedding Dress

Once Umberto caught sight of Marie-Jos√© of Belgium in her wedding dress, he made the already ominous situation even worse. Umberto fumed that the seamstresses had sewn Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs sleeves on backward and demanded that they change them. By the end of it, Marie-Jos√© simply resolved to wear long white gloves instead of the sleeves.

Somehow, that wasn‚Äôt even the most awkward part of her wedding day.

14. She Met Il Duce

By marrying into the Italian royal family, Marie-Jos√© had inadvertently stepped into a world of intense court intrigues. Some years before, a vicious dictator had seized control of the real power in Italy: Benito Mussolini, AKA Il Duce. Mussolini had more or less strong-armed the royal family into bending to his will. But Marie-Jos√© was no regular royal.

15. She Signed Her Own Name

At her wedding, Marie-Jos√© of Belgium made it very clear that, unlike her new in-laws, she would not bend to Mussolini‚Äôs will. When Mussolini insisted that she sign the wedding registry as ‚ÄúMaria Giuseppina‚Äù, forsaking her Belgian heritage, she bluntly refused. In her first sign of defiance against a ruthless dictator, she signed her own name.

Thankfully, not everything that day went horribly wrong.

16. She Got Lavish Gifts

The people of Italy as well as foreign dignitaries hoped that Marie-Jos√© might inject some new blood into the royal family and pull them back from Mussolini‚Äôs extremism. As such, they showered her with lavish gifts. Some of her gifts included a resplendent turquoise and diamond jewelry set and a diamond bow that she wore as decoration on her sash during state occasions.

The other ‚Äúgifts‚Äù from her marriage were a lot less shiny.

17. She Did Her Duty

To anyone paying attention, it had been obvious from the very beginning; Marie-Jos√© of Belgium and Umberto were not in love. Their marriage was simply a matter of political necessity. Unhappy as their marriage might have been, however, Marie-Jos√© still did her royal duty and produced four children between 1934 and 1943. But she was just getting started.

18. She Saved Many Lives

Marie-Jos√© had come a long way from the spoiled child she had once been‚Äîand the world took notice. In 1939, the Red Cross in Italy made the Princess of Piedmont the President of their organization. She had absolutely no idea just how instrumental she would be in preventing the loss of life in the dark days that lay ahead.

19. She Was Against The Axis Forces

At the outbreak of WWII, Marie-Jos√© found herself in an impossible situation. The Italian royal family that she married into had vouched their support for Mussolini and the Axis forces. But, as a Belgian, she could not bring herself to turn her back on her family. What she did next would have potentially dire consequences.

20. She Turned Her Back On Her In-Laws

Under the cover of secrecy, Marie-Jos√© of Belgium made a bold and potentially fatal decision. She was going to defy Mussolini. Behind the dictator‚Äôs back‚Äîand without the blessing of her in-laws‚ÄîMarie-Jos√© tried to negotiate a peace deal with the United States. She even set up a meeting with the future Pope Paul VI to broker the deal.

And that wasn‚Äôt the only way that she worked against the evil Axis forces from within.

21. She Plotted Against Mussolini

From within the walls of the castle and the halls of power, Marie-Jos√© worked tirelessly to undermine Mussolini‚Äôs regime and spare the lives of Italians. She held regular meetings with anti-Mussolini intellectuals, contacted leaders of the Italian Resistance, and supplied the rebel forces with both money and arms. And she soon reaped a huge reward.

22. She Was The Only Smart One In The Family

Once the Americans entered the fight, it wasn‚Äôt long before the Axis forces began to lose their grip on power. Eventually, in large part thanks to Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs efforts, Italy successfully defected to the Allied side. A traveling British diplomat in Italy famously quipped that Marie-Jos√© was the only member of the Italian regime ‚Äúwith good political judgment‚Äù.

Her romantic judgment, however, was terrible.

23. She Was On Mussolini‚Äôs ‚ÄúList‚Äù

As Marie-Jos√© of Belgium worked behind the scenes, Mussolini had grown increasingly unpopular. Quite apart from his wacky political ideas, he was also just a cad. Everyone knew that he was ‚Äúcompulsively promiscuous‚Äù, reportedly sleeping with one woman a day for the almost 14-years of his regime. Shockingly, Marie-Jos√© found herself wrapped up in Mussolini‚Äôs personal melodrama.

24. She Seduced Mussolini

In her diaries, Mussolini‚Äôs mistress, Claretta Petacci, made a shocking disclosure. According to Petacci, Mussolini told her that Marie-Jos√© had once tried to seduce the dictator and entice him into her bed. The alleged ‚Äúseduction‚Äù occurred at Castelporziano, one of the king‚Äôs hunting estates where Mussolini entertained his lovers.

The details of the supposed encounter were actually quite cringe-inducing.

25. She Bared It All

Petacci provided lurid details of the supposed encounter between Marie-Jos√© of Belgium and Mussolini. The dictator‚Äôs mistress quoted the man himself as having told her: ‚ÄúMarie-Jos√© came [up to me] and said 'May I?' Then, with a small movement her dress fell and she was there virtually [unclothed]." The lascivious dictator‚Äôs reaction defied all logic.

26. She Was ‚ÄúRepulsive‚Äù

In her diary confessions, Petacci continued to impugn Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs character with her sensational accusations. She went on to claim that Mussolini reassured her that he had turned down the Princess‚Äô offer, going so far as to call her ‚Äúrepulsive‚Äù. But, if we are to believe another person from Mussolini‚Äôs inner-circle, that was a blatant lie.

27. Her Secrets Came Out

In 1971, Mussolini‚Äôs youngest son, Romano, wrote a letter to Antonio Terzi, a former editor with the newspaper Corriere della Sera. In the letter, Romano made even more shocking allegations than Petacci. In fact, Romano painted the picture of a love affair so torrid that it possibly changed the course of WWII and saved Italy from destruction.

28. She Had An ‚ÄúExplicit‚Äù Affair

In Romano‚Äôs letter to Terzi, he directly contradicted Petacci. ‚ÄúI can confirm in all good faith,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúthat the romantic and political relations between Marie-Jos√© and my father were often talked about at home‚Äù. Romano even went on to confirm that his own mother, Mussolini‚Äôs wife Rachele, gave an ‚Äúexplicit‚Äù account of the affair.

29. She Got Dumped

No one knows exactly how Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs affair with Mussolini began. But Romano shed some light on how it ended. The dictator‚Äôs son‚Äôs letters confirmed that there had been, as he described it ‚Äúa brief period of intimate romantic relations‚Äù between Marie-Jos√© and Mussolini. But it ended abruptly, he asserted, ‚Äúat the instance of my father‚Äù.

Still, people speculated about the truth of these allegations.

30. She Was A Lioness

Given her staunch opposition to Mussolini‚Äôs politics, it was hard for anyone to believe that she had any relations with the man‚Äîfar be it carnal ones. However, in a 1993 interview, Marie-Jos√© all but confirmed the speculation herself. ‚ÄúHe was a lion,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI, too, am a lion. And we both feared one another‚Äù. He wasn‚Äôt the only dictator she made tremble in his boots.

Or, beg to be in her bed.

31. She Faced The F√ºhrer

When the Third Reich invaded Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs homeland of Belgium, the Princess of Piedmont sprung into action. She immediately organized a meeting with the mad F√ºhrer himself in which she demanded mercy for her brother, King Leopold III, whom Axis forces had confined to his castle. She also demanded that the people of Belgium, who were starving, receive better treatment.

The answer she got back was heartbreaking.

32. Her Eyes Were Mesmerizing

Despite her boldness, the F√ºhrer turned down Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs simple requests for the humane treatment of her people. From the sounds of it, he was simply too distracted to remember what she was asking for. The loathsome F√ºhrer later admitted that he had been impressed with Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs beauty, saying that her eyes were ‚Äúthe [color] of the German sky‚Äù.

Her own reply was blood-curdling.

33. She Wished She Had Just Ended The Guy

While the F√ºhrer fawned over Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs beauty, she fumed over his heartlessness. After her unsuccessful meeting with the most reviled man in the world, Marie-Jos√© confessed that she wished she had used another tactic in their negotiations. She admitted that she wished she had taken a revolver into the room and put a slug between his eyes.

‚ÄúI think I would have had the strength to do it,‚Äù she fumed.

34. Her In-Laws Found Out

Eventually, the rest of the royal family along with Mussolini became aware of Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs actions to undermine the Axis forces. Of course, they could not imprison the sitting Princess of Piedmont but they could punish her all the same. Mussolini exiled Marie-Jos√© and her children to Sarre, in the Aosta Valley, where she couldn‚Äôt cause any trouble.

Or so they thought.

35. Her Crown Was Close

Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs efforts, however unsanctioned, had not gone in vain. Once Italy defected to the Allies, her maligned father-in-law, King Victor Emmanuel III, had no choice but to withdraw from government. Naturally, as the next in line to the crown, her husband became regent with the title of Lieutenant General of the Realm.

But the question remained: had her father-in-law damaged the monarchy beyond repair?

36. She Hoped To Save The Monarchy

In an effort to distance themselves from Victor Emmanuel III and restore some dignity to the monarchy, Marie-Jos√© of Belgium and Umberto toured Italy. Arriving in towns and cities ravaged by the fighting with open hearts, Marie-Jos√© and Umberto left a good impression on their subjects. They hoped, against the odds, that they had done enough to save the Italian crown in the upcoming referendum.

They soon found out the truth.

37. She Couldn‚Äôt Defy The Will Of The People

King Victor Emmanuel III only officially abdicated in favor of his son a few weeks before the referendum. By that time, not even Marie-Jos√© could repair the monarchy‚Äôs reputation. On May 9, 1946 Marie-Jos√© became Queen consort of Italy. But, when the people voted to abolish the monarchy just one month later, she lost her crown.

Her consolation prize kinda sucked.

38. She Could Have Done More

Royal watchers praised Marie-Jos√© of Belgium for her actions throughout WWII but criticized her and Umberto for being too ineffectual. As a consolation prize, however, Marie-Jos√© went to bed at night knowing that, had her father-in-law abdicated sooner, she may well have saved the monarchy. But that‚Äôs not how it went down. The reality was far darker.

39. She Had To Leave Italy

Thankfully, the mobs of angry Italians didn‚Äôt take their frustration out on Marie-Jos√© the way they did on her former lover and his associates. Nevertheless, for the country to move forward, she had to go. The new government exiled the remnants of the Italian royal family and banned their male heirs from ever setting foot on Italian soil.

Her remaining years would not be easy ones.

40. She Separated From Her Husband

Marie-Jos√© of Belgium and her family first settled in Portugal but, without the crown to keep them together, the fractures in their marriage grew wider. Marie-Jos√© chose to separate from Umberto, taking their four children with her to Switzerland and leaving Umberto behind. However, as a devout Catholic, she never asked to divorce her estranged‚Äîand‚Äîdeposed husband.

41. She Founded A Foundation

Once in Switzerland, Marie-Jos√© managed to find some measure of peace. Freed from the obligations that had burdened her whole life, Marie-Jos√© spent her days rekindling her love for the arts. She even set up a musical foundation, Fondation du Prix de Composition Reine Marie-Jos√©, that, to this day, still gives awards to budding musicians.

But family trouble disrupted her musical reverie.

42. Her Daughter Was Not Well

Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs youngest daughter brought the Italian royal family to the brink once again. In 1967, she sparked controversy when she tried to marry the Italian actor, Maurizio Arena. Marie-Jos√© immediately filed a lawsuit against the marriage, claiming that her daughter was not mentally well enough to enter into a marriage.

All‚Äôs well that ends well, however.

43. She Kept The Family Together

Marie-Jose‚Äôs youngest daughter eventually ended the relationship with Arena. A few years later, she made a decision that her mother could approve of, marrying the Mexican aristocrat Luis Rafael Reyna-Corval√°n y Dillon. Marie-Jos√© even endorsed the union by living with her daughter and grandchildren in Mexico for a few years.

But her country was calling her back home.

44. Her Husband Never Went Back Home

In 1983, Marie-Jos√© of Belgium and the Italian royal family suffered another tragedy. This time, it was Umberto. The ‚ÄúMay King‚Äù passed away in Geneva at the age of 78, having never returned to his homeland after the family‚Äôs exile. Moreover, he never reconciled with Marie-Jos√©. However, there was one good thing about her husband‚Äôs demise.

45. She Made A Comeback

With the passage of time‚Äîand the last King of Italy‚Äîthe hardened hearts of the Italian people had begun to soften. Prior to Umberto‚Äôs passing, the then-president of Italy had lobbied unsuccessfully to allow the former king to draw his final breaths on Italian soil. However, once Umberto was gone, Marie-Jos√© was free to return to Italy.

46. She Lived To A Ripe Old Age

While the ban on male heirs remained in place, Marie-Jos√© finally returned to Italy. And it looks like the Italian air was good for her. After spending many long years in her former queendom, she passed away on January 27, 2001, in a clinic in Geneva at the age of 94. It was only natural, then, that she received a queen‚Äôs farewell.

47. She Had A Big Funeral

Despite their opinions on the monarchy itself, the people of Italy had always adored Marie-Jos√©. So, when she passed away, the country mourned her loss. Her funeral took place at Hautecombe Abbey in Savoy where 2,000 mourners turned out to show their respects. Even more impressive than the numbers, however, was the guest list.

48. She Was Still Royalty

By the time that Marie-Jos√© passed away, few monarchies remained. However, amongst those that did, she held a special place. King Albert II of the Belgians, King Juan Carlos I of Spain and Farah Pahlavi, the last Empress of Iran all attended Marie-Jos√©‚Äôs funeral and watched as she was buried alongside her (still estranged) husband.

Ironically, her passing revived the monarchy.

49. She Paved The Way For Other Royals

With the loss of their former queen consort, the Italian public went into a state of grieving. In a twist that no one could have anticipated, that grief paved the way for the relaxing of the ban on male heirs from returning to Italy. Just one year after she passed, her grandson, Emanuele Filiberto of Savoy, Prince of Venice, went to Italy having never set foot on Italian soil before.

50. She Was Not Much For Monarchy Anyway
